question: With which tags is the <source> element associated?

answers.c: It is interchangeable with the `src` attribute, so any element which uses `src` may use `<source>`

question: When should you use <ol> and <ul> elements?

answers.a: Use `<ul>` when you want a bulleted list and `<ol>` when you want a numbered list.
answers.b: Use `<ul>` when you have a list of items in which the order of the items matters. Use `<ol>` when you have a list of items that could go in any order.
answers.c: Use `<ol>` when you want a bulleted list and `<ul>` when you want a numbered list.
answers.d: Use `<ol>` when you have a list of items in which the order of the items matters. Use `<ul>` when you have a list of items that could go in any order.

question: What is the difference between the post and get methods in a form?

answers.a: post is used for sending information to the server. get is used for retrieving form information from the server.
answers.b: get is used for sending information to the server. post is used for retrieving form information from the server.
answers.c: With get, data is included in the form body when send to the server. With post, the data goes through the URL.
answers.d: With post, data is included in the form body when send to the server. With get, the data goes through the URL.

question: What is the difference between the <div> and <span> tags?

answers.a: `<div>` is used where a generic block-level tag is needed, while `<span>` is used where a generic inline tag is needed.
answers.b: `<div>` is used for major divisions on a page, while `<span>` is used to span across columns.
answers.c: `<div>` is the industry-standard default tag, but you could use `<span>` if you prefer.
answers.d: `<div>` is used where a generic inline tag is needed, while `<span>` is used where a generic block-level tag is needed.

question: What is the difference between the `<head>` and `<header>` tags in HTML?

answers.a: There is only one `<head>` tag per page, while there may be many `<header>` tags.
answers.b: The `<head>` tag may contain CSS and Javascript links, while the `<header>` tag may contain headings and navigational links.
answers.d: The `<head>` tag contains meta information, while the `<header>` tag contains navigation, logos, and other page identifying content.

answers.a: It labels webpages with important information.
answers.b: It visually associates a text label with an interface element.
answers.d: It programmatically associates a text label with an interface element.

question: Which statement is true about the defer attribute of the HTML script tag?

answers.a: The defer attribute can work synchronously.
answers.b: The defer attribute works only with generators.
answers.c: The defer attribute works only with promises.
answers.d: The defer attribute will asynchronously load the scripts in order.

question: Which tag is the root element of an HTML document?
What is the purpose of the async keyword in a script tag?

answers.a: It will download the script from the server when resources allow.
answers.b: It will run the script after HTML parsing is complete.
answers.c: It makes the script run when the script is ready.
answers.d: It pauses the parsing of HTML code while the script runs.

question:

question: How do you confirm that a document is written in HTML5?

answers.a: The server wraps the webpage in an HTML5 wrapper.
answers.b: There should be a `<!DOCTYPE html>` declaration that starts the document.
answers.c: The browser receives encoding from the server to display the document with HTML5.
answers.d: It is enclosed in a `<html>` tag.

question: What is the semantic use of the <hr> ?

answers.a: This tag is depreciated and should not be used.
answers.b: It designates a topic shift within a section at the paragraph level.
answers.d: It designates a shift of topic at the section level.

question: What do you use the <label> tag for?

answers.a: To labels webpages with important information.
answers.b: To visually associates a text label with an interface element.
answers.d: To programmatically associates a text label with an interface element.

question: What does the **poster** attribute do in the `<video>` tag?

answers.a: It specifies an image that should display while the video downloads and until the video is played.
answers.b: It specifies an image that only displays if there is a problem with the video.
answers.c: It specifies an image that should display until the video is played.
answers.d: It specifies an image that should display while the video downloads.

question: Which of these image formats is supported by all web browsers?
Which of these statement is FALSE ?

answers.a: Inline elements can be nested inside inline elements.
answers.b: Block elements can be nested inside block elements.
answers.c: Inline elements can be nested inside block elements.
answers.d: Block elements can be nested inside inline elements.
